feed.title: Misfits: TV's Unlikely Heroes
feed.subtitle: Misfits is a popular British dramedy about a ragtag group of juvenile delinquents who received supernatural powers in a freak lightning storm.

category.term: British Academy of Film and Television Arts

content.div:
Where the Avengers assemble, the Misfits are more likely to stumble. Where the X-Men fight for civil rights, the Misfits fight to stay sober - and to finish their community service.

Welcome to the world of Misfits, the popular British dramedy about a ragtag group of juvenile delinquents who received supernatural powers in a freak lightning storm. Season 3 is currently airing in Canada on Showcase, and that might just be the beginning of things to come. Josh Schwartz, the writer/producer behind The OC, Gossip Girl and Chuck, is currently peddling a U.S. remake of the award-winning series. Given the success of the original - Misfits has won repeated honours from the British Academy of Film and Television - it's hard to imagine Schwartz not finding takers for his pilot.

Iwan Rheon, who plays the British Misfits' de facto leader, Simon, said it took a long time for the show's characters to gel. Not every super-powered youth has an Uncle Ben to teach them that, "With great power comes great responsibility," or a Jonathan Kent preaching folksy, homespun values on a family farm.

"They've sort of grown into a codependency on each other - now they're friends," Rheon said in a recent phone interview. "The great thing at the beginning is that they all kind of hated each other. Now they've realized that they need to help each other, and they've formed this weird sort of unit. . . . They like each other now, they look after each other."

While Misfits' characters are often self-centred and self-destructive - not to mention almost comically inept - Rheon said the strong writing has allowed the gritty, dysfunctional group to connect with audiences.

"They always keep you guessing, they're not stereotypical," he said. "Although they are very strong archetypes, I feel that there is a three-dimensional feel to all the characters - there's a depth. . . . People really identify with at least some of the characters, if not (all of them)."

The third season has already aired in the U.K. But neither Rheon nor Antonia Thomas, who plays Simon's girlfriend Alicia, will be back for Season 4. Canadian fans will have to wait for the explosive season finale to find out the fate of the star-struck lovers.

For Rheon, the finale might be his favourite episode of the whole series. In general, the third season has a more epic feel; the stakes are just plain higher, he explained. "It just got bigger. The storylines are becoming more elaborate. The world is really opening up."

Rheon is confident the series will survive another change in casting. The group dynamic was already shaken up for Season 3 with the departure of Robert Sheehan, who played the foul-mouthed, sex-crazed Nathan in the first two seasons. While Sheehan was one of the show's breakout stars, his replacement this year - Rudy (played by Joseph Gilgun) - has fit into the show's dynamic effortlessly. Gifted with the ability to literally split in two, Rudy's character has provided new fodder for Misfits' black, off-kilter comedy.

"What Joe has brought is more of a . . . crazy-drummer, Keith Moon-type character, compared to Robert's Mick Jagger," Rheon said. "You have to remember that Robert didn't write the script. He was a brilliant part of the show, but his lines were written for him - though his delivery is fantastic and he's such a talented actor. We all just trusted in the writers, and I hope that carries on. They'll find other actors and the show will go on. It has very talented people behind it who are very passionate."

The end of Season 2 offered a game-changer, with the Misfits visiting a power "dealer," a man with the ability to trade people's powers. Season 3 has found the whole cast exploring new talents. Imagine Batman learning to fly overnight, or Spider-Man suddenly learning to see the future.

"It's very clever; it just completely opens everything up," Rheon said of the power-swapping concept. "You have a lot more people with powers now coming to the forefront."

Despite being the world's most unlikely saviours, Rheon thinks the group has the capacity for heroism.

"I think Simon, in particular, is very much (evolving into a real hero); the others may have to get pushed into it a little bit more by him," he said. "You see, in this series, they will save the world."

Simon himself has gone from a shy, social outcast to the group's increasingly confident leader and backbone. Season 3 finds Simon haunted by the discovery that a mysterious, masked figure, who has been assisting the group, is actually himself from the future. Future Simon dies saving Alisha, leaving Simon under pressure to become that same heroic figure.

"He has a real sense of purpose," he said. "Although it's a challenge he enjoys, I think it's a quite frightening place (to be in)."

Rheon said he is looking forward to seeing an American version of the series, but noted the storyline may have to be expanded if airing on U.S. network television.

"I think it's important that they keep these shows pure," he said. "You don't want to water it down (and) lose any of the impact or reasons it was so good in the first place. They just have to be really careful of that."

While the new version will have to be tweaked for cultural differences, Rheon thinks one ingredient is essential. "It struck a chord with young people. As long as you keep that, you'll be fine."

Schwartz wrote the American pilot with Misfits creator Howard Overman, who will also serve as co-executive producer if a U.S. version takes flight.

"I hope we get to make it," Schwartz excitedly told The Huffington Post in December. "I'm working with Howard Overman . . . so I'm playing the guide, and it's really his baby. I'm a huge fan of (Misfits), and that's my role on the show, as a fan."

Misfits airs Thursday at 10 ET/PT on Showcase.

clackner@postmedia.com
